revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox military person |name=Michał Karaszewicz-Tokarzewski |image=M. Karaszewicz-Tokarzewski.jpg |rank=[[Lieutenant General]] |death_date={{death date and age|1964|5|22|1893|1|5|df=y}} |death_place=[[Casablanca]], [[Morocco]] |birth_date={{birth date|1893|1|5|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Lviv|Lwów]], [[Austria-Hungary]] |serviceyears=1918 - 1945 |commands=[[19th Infantry Division (Poland)|19th Infantry Division]]
[[25th Infantry Division (Poland)|25th Infantry Division]]
[[6th Infantry Division (Poland)|6th Infantry Division]] |battles= |awards=[[File:POL Virtuti Militari Komandorski BAR.svg|40px|Virtuti Militari Commander's Cross]] [[File:Virtuti Militari Ribbon.png|40px|Virtuti Militari Silver Medal]] [[File:Polonia Restituta Komandorski.jpg|40px|Polonia Restituta Commander's Cross]] [[File:Polonia Restituta Oficerski.jpg|40px|Polonia Restituta Knight's Cross]]
[[File:Krzyz Niepodleglosci z Mieczami.gif|40px|Krzyz Niepodleglosci with Swords]] [[File:POL Krzyż Walecznych (1940) 4r BAR.PNG|40px]] [[File:Krzyz Zaslugi Ribbon.png|40px|Krzyz Zaslugi]] }} '''General Michał Tadeusz Karaszewicz-Tokarzewski''', [[Coat of arms of Trąby]] pseudonym '''Doktor''', '''Stolarski''', '''Torwid'''Jozef Garlinski ''Poland in the Second World War'', ISBN 0-333-39258-2 Page 40 (b. 5 January 1893 in [[Lviv|Lwów]] - 22 May 1964 in [[Casablanca]], [[Morocco]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] general, founder of the [[resistance movement]] "[[Polish Victory Service]]". ==Early life== Tokarzewski served in the [[Polish Legions in World War I|Polish Legions]] from 1914 until 1917, then in the [[Polska Organizacja Wojskowa|POW]] (Polish Military Organization). He was a commanding officer of the "5th Infantry Legion Regiment" during the [[Polish-Ukrainian War]], which fought in Lwów.Rosa Bailly ''A city fights for freedom'' Leopolis 1956 Pages 276-310 After Poland regained independence in 1918, Tokarzewski served in the [[Polish Army]]. In April 1919 he participated in the Polish-Soviet War, when [[Wilno]] was seized by Poland. From 1924 until 1926 he was commanding the [[19th Infantry Division (Poland)|19th Infantry Division]] in Wilno, from 1928 until 1932 a commanding officer of the [[25th Infantry Division (Poland)|25th Infantry Division]] in [[Kalisz]] and from 1932 until 1939 a commanding officer of the Corps area (okreg korpusu) in [[Grodno]], Lwów and [[Toruń]]. ==World War II== [[File:Tokarzewski Michal LOC matpc 12499.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Michał Tokarzewski as the second in command of the Anders Army while in [[Jerusalem]] during World War II.]] During the [[Invasion of Poland (1939)|Polish Defensive War]] of 1939, he was commanding the Operation Group (grupa operacyjna) of the "[[Armia Pomorze]]" (Pomeranian Army). He fought in the [[Battle of Bzura]] and was the second-in-command of "[[Armia Warszawa]]" (Army Warsaw) which was commanded by general [[Juliusz Rómmel]], during the [[Siege of Warsaw (1939)|defence of Warsaw]]. In occupied Poland, on 27 September 1939 he founded the [[resistance movement]] "[[Służba Zwycięstwu Polski]]" (Polish Victory Service)Norman Davies ''God's Playground VolumeII'' Clarendon, 1986 ISBN 0-19-821944-X Page 464 and was its commander-in-chief until December 1939, when he became the commanding officer of the "3rd Lwów area ([[ZWZ]])"Jozef Garlinski ''Poland in the Second World War'', ISBN 0-333-39258-2 Page 50 under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation. Crossing the new German-Soviet border, in March 1940 he was arrested and imprisoned by the [[NKVD]].Jozef Garlinski ''Poland in the Second World War'', ISBN 0-333-39258-2 Page 51 After being released from prison, Tokarzewski was appointed a commanding officer of the "6th Infantry Division" of the Polish Army in the [[Soviet Union]] ([[Władysław Anders|Anders Army]]) in August 1941. From March 1943 until 1944 he served as the second-in-command of the Polish Army in the East. In 1944 he became a commander of the [[3rd Polish Corps]] which was formed in [[Egypt]]. ==After World War II== [[File:Michał Karaszewicz-Tokarzewski gravestone.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Michał Tokarzewski gravestone in [[Brompton Cemetery]], London.]] After the war he stayed in exile in [[England]] and settled in London. From 1954 on he was the [[General Inspector of the Armed Forces]] of the Polish forces in exile. He died on 22 May 1964 in [[Casablanca, Morocco]]. In September 1992 the urn with his ashes was transferred from [[Brompton Cemetery]] in London to [[Poland]] and buried at the [[Powązki Cemetery]] in [[Warsaw]]. In 2006, General Tokarzewski's medals and battledress came up for public auction. Two [[Canadians]], who were aware of the unfortunate history of Poland during World War II, were successful in their bid and brought the items to Canada. The two then donated the entire collection to "Poland and the Polish people" during a ceremony at the [[Polish Combatants' Association, Branch#20]], in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]]. The collection was displayed at the Branch #20 museum until March, 2007, when it was shipped to [[Warsaw]] to be displayed in the Warsaw [[Museum#military museum|Military Museum]] in that city. == Awards == * Commander of the [[Virtuti Militari]] Order * Commander of the [[Order of Polonia Restituta]] * [[Krzyż Niepodległości]] (Cross of Independence), with Swords * [[Krzyż Walecznych]] (Cross of Valour), 4 times * [[Krzyż Zasługi|Złoty Krzyż Zasługi z Mieczami]] (Gold Cross of Merit with Swords), twice * [[Order of the White Eagle (Poland)|Order of the White Eagle]] (posthumously in 1964 by the Polish authorities in exile) [[File:Herb Traby.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Traby Coat of Arms]] {{s-start}} {{s-mil|}} {{succession box|title=[[Service for Poland's Victory|Commander of the Service for Poland's Victory]]|before=Polish Restsiance movement established|after=[[Stefan Rowecki]]
([[Armia Krajowa]])|years=1939–1940}} {{succession box|title=[[General Inspector of the Armed Forces]]|before=[[Władysław Anders]]|after=[[Stefan Dembiński]]|years=1954–1964}} {{s-end}} == See also == * [[Armia Krajowa]] * [[2nd Polish Corps]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{AK Commanders}} {{General Inspectors of the Polish Armed Forces}} {{Armia Krajowa}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karaszewicz-Tokarzewski, Michal}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1964 deaths]] [[Category:People from Lviv]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Galicia and Lodomeria]] [[Category:Clan of Trąby]] [[Category:Polish Socialist Party politicians]] [[Category:Polish generals]] [[Category:Polish Military Organisation members]] [[category:Polish Freemasons]] [[Category:Polish Theosophists]] [[Category:Polish legionnaires (World War I)]] [[Category:Polish people of the Polish–Ukrainian War]] [[Category:Polish people of the Polish–Soviet War]] [[Category:People of the Polish May Coup (pro-Piłsudski side)]] [[Category:Polish resistance fighters of World War II]] [[Category:Failed assassins of Adolf Hitler]] [[Category:Polish people detained by the NKVD]] [[Category:Commanders of the Virtuti Militari]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Independence with Swords]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Polonia Restituta]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Valour (Poland)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Gold Cross of Merit (Poland)]] [[Category:Burials at Powązki Cemetery]]
